title: 107_hr2662
content: SECTION 1. REMOVAL OF PROVISIONS RESTRICTING TRADE AND OTHER RELATIONS WITH CUBA. The authorities under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 and the Trading With the Enemy Act regarding Cuba are repealed. Any export prohibitions to Cuba in effect before the effective date of the Act will be removed. On the effective date of this Act, export controls on Cuba under the Export Administration Act of 1979 will cease. The President can impose new export restrictions on Cuba under certain acts and exercise emergency powers if a national security threat arises. The Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity Act of 1996 are repealed, including related amendments to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by striking certain paragraphs and subsections in various sections of different acts. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing references to Cuba in specific sections and subsections. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended by removing sections 909, 910, and redesignating section 911 as section 909. Additionally, the prohibition on transactions or payments with respect to certain United States intellectual property is repealed, and the denial of foreign tax credit with respect to Cuba is terminated. The Trade Sanctions Reform and Export Enhancement Act of 2000 is amended to remove sections 909, 910, and redesignate section 911 as section 909. The prohibition on transactions or payments related to certain United States intellectual property is repealed, and the denial of foreign tax credit for Cuba is terminated. Additionally, Section 902(c) of the Food Security Act of 1985, which pertains to sugar quota prohibition, is repealed. SEC. 2. TELECOMMUNICATIONS EQUIPMENT AND FACILITIES. Any common carrier authorized to install, maintain, and repair telecommunications equipment in Cuba and provide services between the United States and Cuba, including upgrades. SEC. 3. TRAVEL. SEC. 3. TRAVEL. Travel to and from Cuba by U.S. citizens or residents, and related transactions, may not be regulated or prohibited if lawful in the U.S. Transactions include travel maintenance and banking involving foreign currency. The United States Postal Service is required to establish direct mail service to and from Cuba, utilizing charter providers if necessary. Federal assistance is prohibited in this matter. No Federal funds may be used to provide any assistance to Cuba, including grants, commercial sales, guaranties, insurance, loans, leases, credits, or reserves that are more favorable than market terms. This includes assistance from the Export-Import Bank of the United States for exports to or imports from Cuba. No Federal funds may be used to provide assistance to Cuba, including insurance, financing, or investment from the Overseas Private Investment Corporation, export credits through the Commodity Credit Corporation, assistance under the Agricultural Trade and Development Assistance Act of 1954, or financing for agricultural commodities exports. No Federal funds may be used for financing or assistance under the Agricultural Trade Act of 1978 to support export sales of agricultural commodities to Cuba, or for any loan, credit, or financing involving confiscated property. Additionally, Cuban debt cannot be exchanged, reduced, or forgiven in return for an equity interest. The term "agency or instrumentality of the Government of Cuba" refers to an agency or instrumentality of a foreign state as defined in the United States Code. The Act will become effective 60 days after its enactment.
